Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: Interacting with the Brain: Mechanisms, Optimization, and Innovation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Traineeship (IGERT) award supports the development of a multi-disciplinary, integrative graduate education and training program in NeuroEngineering (NE) at the University of Minnesota at Twin Cities. Intellectual Merit: The purpose of this program is to train doctoral students to develop the skills to revolutionize technologies for interfacing with the brain and advance the fundamental understanding of neuroscience processes that arise when interfacing with and modulating the brain.

Broader impacts include the development of a multi-disciplinary training program that blurs the boundary between neuroscientists and engineers, thus enabling a new generation of scientists to competently and confidently take on the grand challenges in the interdisciplinary field of NeuroEngineering. The NE program includes major research themes in decoding brain signals, modulating brain dynamics, and bi-directional brain interfacing. The program is a "degree-plus" model in which pre-doctoral students are admitted to one of the participating graduate programs (Biomedical Engineering, Electrical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, and Neuroscience), and are trained through a series of hands-on, modular neuroengineering courses. All NE Fellows will immerse themselves in a lab outside their major in the summer of their first year, engage in multiple lab rotations, and participate in at least one clinical lab rotation, summer internship at a neurotechnology company, or summer international research experience. NE Fellows will have co-advisors beginning in their first year, one from the engineering sciences and one from the basic or clinical neurosciences. The training program incorporates several outreach efforts to recruit women and underrepresented minorities, provide outreach to K-12 and industry, and train NE Fellows to be effective communicators.

IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Neural interface technologies, including systems that electrically pace brain activity to restore function or use brain activity to diagnose disease or control a computer, have tremendous potential to improve quality of life. The University of Minnesota Neural Engineering IGERT (NE-IGERT) program was motivated by the notion that future breakthroughs in this rapidly-growing area of research will be made by engineers who understand the fundamental issues and principles of neuroscience that occur during neural interventions, and by neuroscientists who are truly competent in engineering concepts and tools. 

Our IGERT program trained 34 doctoral students in four major interdisciplinary research themes: a) modulating brain signals with stimulation, b) decoding brain signals to control systems, c) assessing brain signals with functional imaging, and d) modeling functional brain networks. The program developed a “degree-plus” model in which trainees worked to achieve a neuroengineering minor in addition to taking coursework in their home department.  Each trainee selected faculty co-mentors (one from engineering and one from the brain sciences), which provided trainees with unique opportunities to engage in high-impact interdisciplinary research starting in their first year of the program.

Trainees also had the opportunity to gain professional experience in applying neuroengineering principles through semester-long internships at several companies that specialize in neuroimaging and neuromodulation products.  Additionally, trainess engaged in numerous outreach and leadership activities from educating 2nd-4th graders through a Brain Awareness Week program to hosting high school students from groups underrepressented in STEM at the University to serving as graduate mentors for summer REU students to helping organize an annual Minnesota Neuromodulation Symposium that provides a forum for world leaders in the emerging field of neuromodulation (academia, industry, and government).

The University of Minnesota Neural Engineering IGERT program generated a number of research products including development of non-invasive brain computer interfaces for human use, high-field MRI (10.5T) for human use, MRI-compatible microelectrodes for measuring neuronal spike activity during fMRI, recording methodologies that combine EEG with transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS), computational models that can predict the biophysical effects of electrical stimulation within the brain and mechanical stimulation of the skin, high-density electrode arrays for interfacing with the brain, and novel signal processing approaches for real-time analysis of neural signals for use in closed-loop brain stimulation applications.
